channel.title: Posts on Coffee now
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Coffee now

item.title: Building an IndieWeb house (I): introduction
item.description: When an email went round at work asking if anyone was up for giving a lunchtime talk on a hobby, I volunteered to do so. I’ve got to be honest that I did suspect ‘static site personal blogging’ might be considered a bit too esoteric for them to accept, but no, they took me up on it. Whelp! That’s now done, so, to record the details, I’m also writing it up as a few blog posts…

item.title: A 2024 reading round up
item.description: Here, I’m bringing together all 19 book reviews I’ve written for fantasy books read in 2024, as originally published on my Bookwyrm account. With the exception of cookbooks, fantasy has always been my most prevalent reading genre (although I’ll admit there’s a bit of presenting myself in a certain way on the internet here as, yes, I do read quite a few light romances too)…

item.title: Spiced damson jam
item.description: Our damson tree had an unusually large crop of fruit this year, so I decided to make a batch of jam. The recipe below details what appears to have worked well. It was adapted from a plum jam recipe found in the book Jams & Chutneys, although the original recipe was for about half the quantity and gave the preparation time as an implausible 20 mins…

item.title: West Highland Way (IV): Ben Nevis and home
item.description: Having reached Fort William in 5 days, I was definitely hoping to climb Ben Nevis but was a bit unsure whether it would be a good idea after the days spent hiking. After my first ‘full’ breakfast of the trip at the BnB, I decided to first deal with where my ‘no plan plan’ was going to meet the rigid schedule of the railways…

item.title: West Highland Way (III): Bridge of Orchy to the end
item.description: As we left the story of my adventure on the West Highland Way, it was 10 pm and I had just set up at the wild camping zone at the Bridge of Orchy having covered 104.3 km of the 154 km trail in 3 days of walking. This meant we now had the wildest section of the route to go…

item.title: West Highland Way (II): the first three days to Bridge of Orchy
item.description: The West Highland Way is the UK’s most popular long-distance path. It’s not hard to work out why – it takes in some of the best of Scotland’s scenery, yet is fairly accessible hiking. Apparently, some 40,000 people complete the entire walk each year, and I was soon to be one of them…

item.title: West Highland Way (I): preparation
item.description: I decided to walk the West Highland Way (running some 96 miles, or 154 km, from Milngavie, just north of Glasgow, to Fort William) after some original solo holiday plans fell through with a couple of months to go. I hence found myself trying to figure out what I’d need to do to walk a long-distance path at relatively short notice…

item.title: LonDONE: a four-year marathon
item.description: I did it! That is, I finally completed the London marathon 21st April 2024, with a time of 6:33:02. Oh my gosh, has this ever been a lot of hard work – I’ve effectively trained for it three times after first the delays of the pandemic pushed it into 2023, then injury meaning I had to defer to 2024. So my initial reaction to crossing the line was really just one of relief…

item.title: London marathon revisited: what if it goes right?
item.description: I’m finally there… that is past the longest run of training, past the last long run of tapering even, and it’s looking more likely than not that 2024 will be the year I really make it to the start line of the London marathon. It’s now ~1.5 weeks to go – I’m nervous, excited…

item.title: An easy-to-print dated A5 planner: the script
item.description: With a lot of hobbies, there’s always the bit that’s the chore. Maybe washing your brushes if you’re painting, figuring out code if you’re blogging, weighing the ingredients if you’re baking (endless washing if you’re running?). With making paper planners, it’s the dating, printing, cutting and punching…

item.title: Happy blogiversary and 2 months on Mastodon
item.description: It was ~2 years ago that we started this blog as a way to share long-form musings or the simple stuff going on on our lives with, well, with anyone who wanted to read it. Then, ~2 months ago, coffeenow also joined the fediverse and now has its own account on Mastodon…

item.title: A new running thing… but not in London
item.description: Ok, so for those who don’t know, the London marathon didn’t happen for me this year. I think I’ve always been clear that there was a bit of an ‘if’ getting to the start line. When you are pushing yourself doing runs that are that far, there’s always a risk of picking up an injury…

item.title: Sandy 10 2023
item.description: I decided to enter the Sandy 10 this year after learning that it was the 40th anniversary of this race and realising that I had run the 30th anniversary race, which I think was my very first race as a member of NHRR…

item.title: No Strava, I didn’t go that fast
item.description: It’s January. And, for a lot of people, at this time of year, there’s a renewed focus on fitness goals. This isn’t quite the case for me, as I’ve been training for the three-year marathon (yep, still plan to do it, injury excepting) since the start of October. Not quite training like I managed in 2019 and early 2020 but…

item.title: Bonfire Burn 2022
item.description: When there’s a big banner for a 10 km race staring at you if you glance out of your office window, it does seem rude not to enter. Mind, this was back pre-pandemic in 2019, not long after I learnt I’d got a 2020 London marathon ballot place and at a point I could actually run a full 10 km…

item.title: Haste to the wedding: the musical interlude
item.description: Amongst the hasty planning of our wedding, it occurred to us that I could provide a musical interlude on the tin whistle that I’ve been learning to play over the last 18 months or so. I was initially a bit hesitant about this (can we say reluctant…)

item.title: Haste to the wedding (II): the day
item.description: Where were we; oh yes, we were eloping to Scotland. Wow. It’s still a little scary to think it. And it’s getting even harder to write about. But here’s part two of the ‘haste to the wedding’ story, from leaving home until the end of the wedding day. And for those who don’t know the reason these posts are entitled ‘haste to the wedding’, it will become apparent…

item.title: Haste to the wedding (I): before the trip
item.description: Well, the secret is out now, after being together 20 years, James and I eloped for a late-summer wedding overlooking the gorgeous Loch Lomond. And as we’ve been asked a few times what prompted this, a blog post seems in order. However, that’s not really so easy to write, not least because this is all quite personal. But, here we are with a little of the story…

item.title: Scones
item.description: I’m writing this on ‘National Cream Tea Day’ not long after I succumbed to scone fever with two recent events requiring the baking of scones. However, it’s not me doing the baking - James is the one who’s rather good at scones - so much so, I call his scones ‘the clouds’. Hence, another recipe-sharing blog post…

item.title: Pitfalls of replacing an icon font with svg icons
item.description: This blog uses a fair few icons, such as the icons in the menu. Until today, these had been placed using a font kit from Font Awesome, which worked by using JavaScript to replace tags with the appropriate icon from their library. However, for some time I’d been wanting to move away from this method…

item.title: Herts Sunday cross country league 21/22 review
item.description: It was great news when I heard that the club had arranged for us to take part in the Herts Sunday cross country league, the winter sister competition to our usual summer interclub competition. As I prepared, I was very pleased to find that I’d had some forethought 2 years ago, and had loosened the spikes in the cross country shoes, so they weren’t rusted in place…

item.title: Jiganuary
item.description: For the past year, I’ve been learning to play the tin whistle from a starting point of very little musical experience. I’m hoping to write more about that process in a future post, but here I’m focusing on my most recent efforts practicing some jigs during January. Hence ‘jiganuary’.

item.title: Happy Christmas puddings
item.description: It’s long past stir-up Sunday but not long past when a blog post on the family Christmas pudding recipe seems a good idea…

item.title: A peck of pickled peppers
item.description: I do love a good kebab - one place I lived even had a fabulous kebab van complete with its own fresh tabbouleh. A staple of the takeaway kebab is also a pickled chilli; I wouldn’t dream of picking it out to throw away…

item.title: Constructing a personalised discbound planner
item.description: Although I love creative hobbies, time is always a factor that means I don’t do them as much as I like. A few years ago, I discovered decorative planning, and this led me into into exploring the concept of making my own personalised planner…

item.title: Duck n Dash 2021 (and 2024)
item.description: Today saw the return of the Duck n Dash aquathlon for its 11th year. This is an annual favourite for me, combining a 400 m lane swim in the Letchworth outdoor pool with a 5 km run round Norton Common…

item.title: The three-year marathon?
item.description: Getting a ballot place in the London marathon is a lucky thing. London marathon don’t publish the number of ballot places that they have, but estimates I’ve read say it’s ~17,000. We do know that there are usually ~40,000 runners…

item.title: Sourdough
item.description: I’ve found myself doing a more than average amount of baking over the last year or so, including bread and in particular sourdough. Here are some notes on the process that I follow to make sourdough…

item.title: Subscription review: SimplyCook
item.description: Subscriptions are everywhere… music, tv, software… you even are, in a way, a subscriber to social media content, notwithstanding that you aren’t very in control of what you see there. Maybe even someone subscribes (via RSS) to this blog, not that I feel that’s very likely…

item.title: Microsoft Word 365: why ‘modern comments’ are awful for editors
item.description: I think it’s a given that whenever there’s some form of software update, I’m going to initially dislike it. First of all, there’s the disruption of the update itself, waiting for something to download and restart until I get my program back, no doubt occurring at the most inconvenient moment. But then there’s also just that it is a change. It’s not that I genuinely hate change of course…

item.title: Setting up the blog (II): initial design decisions
item.description: In my previous post about setting up the blog, we were at the stage of having decided on, and got at least somewhere, with getting Hugo working to generate a website, but with much design still to do. And although design can be just going with your preferred template for the content, I want a little more input than that because I do just want a ‘feel’ that says ‘coffee now’ to me, like when you’re sat on the sofa with a coffee.

item.title: Procreate with a Holly Pixel’s tutorial
item.description: Text or other blocky elements entwined with background images is a look that’s often used in stickers and planners, and although it looks doable - it’s only combining a few elements together - I hadn’t even worked out how to use custom fonts on Procreate, let alone how to only show part of a rasterised text layer without just erasing. But now, after following along with a tutorial published by Holly Pixels (update from the future: no longer available), I’ve at least got somewhere on it.

item.title: Giants, chocolate bars and mass running events
item.description: It’s blowing a hooley out there again, pun intended. Unfortunately, it also did the same on my return to running club this week; sunny before, sunny after, but during a torrential thunderstorm. Two days later and I might be dry but my trainers are still sopping. It’s also the day parkrun, a worldwide organisation that helps volunteers run free, weekly, timed 5k events, of which there are hundreds in the UK have confirmed their events won’t be back in England on June 5th; but more on that later.

item.title: Setting up the blog (I): getting started with Hugo
item.description: When you make the decision to start a blog, one of the first things you need to consider is what sort of system you’re going to use to organise your content. If you read any article on starting out blogging, it will almost certainly mention WordPress. WordPress (meaning software available at https://wordpress.org, not to be confused with WordPress.com; see below) is a very common open-source content management system (CMS) for creating websites, including, but far from limited to, those dedicated to blogging.

item.title: Pizza test post
item.description: Hello world. This is our first blog post. We are writing about pizza because pizza is the best. After coffee. It’s a post only to learn how to do a post, and show pizza.
